Title: AYES
text: Orange juice, and the citrus growers of Australia are affected. Now all these other extra taxes and impositions on this country are coming out into the open. What about the Medicare levy? The Government put that up. The private hospital subsidy was taken away. Today half the sick people in Australia are in private hospitals. Pharmaceutical benefits for pensioners have been taken away. I have spoken about the' delay in introducing tax cuts. I spoke about petrol. Last Friday the price of diesel for the primary producers of this country went up by approximately 6c a litre. The farmers in this country will pay more for their diesel fuel. Fuel costs today are one of the greatest contributors to farm costs. Under this Government the poor get poorer and the rich get richer, but this is typical of socialism in a country. Honourable members opposite know that what I say is quite correct. I would like to say something about taxation. Of course there must be reform. Taxation reform must give incentive to the individual to work and to expand business. I remind honourable members opposite that President Reagan, upon coming to office, reduced taxation by 20 per cent and created over six million new jobs. The taxation reform that we look for in Australia must allow for income splitting for families, spreading the burden across the taxpayers of the country and allowing for a reduction in personal taxation. The Government must have confidence. Is it necessary for the Commonwealth to be involved, as it is, in such areas as education housing, Medicare and other important areawhich I believe should be left to private enterprise or the States? Political analysts have demonstrated in recent times how easy it would be to save at least $7.5 billion from our Budget are all very each year in government costs. I talk in general terms, because it is important that we do so. I would love to talk more about milk and petrol, I would love to talk more about the farmers, but I raise a matter that was discussed this afternoon in the Parliament· that is the allocation in the Budget for the A-straliaBroadcasting Corporation. I am worried about regional television. The measures the Government intends to adopt are not in the interests of country people generally. It is all very well for the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) to say: 'If television stations want to aggregate country people will have the opportunity to see three commercial stations'. In country areas we are accustomed to seeing local news, local issues and local advertising on television. I believe that the cost of equalisation, the cost of the coverage of at least three stations-particularly on the north coast and in the north-west of New South Wales-will make it extremely expensive for advertisers, will adversely affect programs and will not bring the equality that we are talking about. It was said in the chamber only this afternoon that it will cost at least $20m for a station to aggregate, to install the equipment. fuel We are concerned with keeping up the standard of our programs and providing the services we would like to see provided, particularly as far as country television is concerned.

Speaker: Mr LINDSAY
Title: AYES
text: -It is an indubitable fact that Australia has as its current Prime Minister one of the greatest leaders this country has produced, a Prime Minister who has a clear vision of the direction his Government should take. The 1986-87 Federal Budget provides that direction-a direction to all Australians to face up to the challenges of a changing world and the direction to achieve the vision we all share for a better Australia. The 1986-87 Federal Budget was, by any standard, a tough Budget. It was a Budget which called for restraint on the part of all sections of our community. Restraint is necessary. For a responsible Federal Government, budgetary restraint was unavoidable. The last 18 months have seen dramatic falls in the world market prices for almost all the primary products exported by Australia. Despite the depreciation of the Australian dollar, the terms of trade for Australian goods since December 1984 have dropped by 13.5 per cent. These price falls are the result of forces totally beyond Australian control. In United States dollar terms, over the past five years coal prices have fallen by 25 per cent, beef prices in the last two years have dropped by a quarter and sugar prices have fallen by half since the late 1970s. The rise in the current account deficit, which is now estimated to be at $14 billion, can be attributed in the main to the devastating change in the international conditions affecting our internationally traded goods. All reasonable Australians know the necessity for restraint. That is why this Budget provides for zero real growth in outlays. This has involved the cutting of nearly $3 billion from the cost of existing programs. The Budget also provides for increased tax raisings of about $1.4 billion. The Government has served notice that it will seek discounting of two percentage points in the next national wage case. In summary, the Budget provides for a deficit of $3.5 billion overall; that is, $6.1 billion less than the deficit inherited from the Fraser-Howard Government. If 1986-87 is to be the year of consolidation of Australia's economy, it is also the year of continuing Hawke Government projects in the Herbert electorate on a scale unmatched elsewhere in Australia. The historic aspirations of the people of the Herbert electorate are being realised at a pace which has drawn resounding acclamation. No government, Federal or State, in the history of Australia has given more aid for the development of north Queensland than has the Hawke Government. Three and a half years ago there was no Burdekin Falls Dam, no new Townsville domestic air terminal, no School of Tourism and Hospitality, no Great Barrier Reef Wonderland project, no Commonwealth Government Centre and no School of Technology, and the Bruce Highway in north Queensland was not only dangerous to motorists but also a disgrace to the previous Liberal-National Party Government. North Queensland needed these Hawke Government projects. It needed the jobs that went with them. I have spoken often in this House of the importance of the Burdekin Dam to Townsville, a city of more than 106,000 people continuously plagued by periods of drought and water restrictions. Without water from the Burdekin Dam, Townsville will not have the capacity to meet the water needs of further industrial development, population growth will be limited and Federal Government plans to expand its defence presence in Townsville will be seriously handicapped. The sum of $29m has been allocated in the Budget for the completion of the Burdekin Falls Dam by March 1987. The Hawke Government is paying the total cost of the $122m Burdekin Dam, surely the greatest national water resources project in Australia since the Snowy Mountains scheme. I record the outstanding achievement of Paul Johnson, Burdekin Dam project engineer, in guiding this project towards completion. The sum of $9.5m has been allocated in the Budget towards the cost of a new domestic air terminal at Townsville. Construction is well advanced. Due for completion in November 1987, the $16m terminal will be able to transit more than 1,200 passengers at anyone time in air-conditioned comfort and will be one of the most functional and attractive air terminals in Australia. The Budget also provides funds for the $20m Great Barrier Reef Wonderland, a Commonwealth-State bicentennial project being developed in Townsville and hailed as unique because it will include the largest live coral reef aquarium in the world, the first omnimax theatre in the southern hemisphere and the first general branch of the Queensland Museum outside Brisbane. The aquarium will create enormous scientific interest in addition to being a spectacular means for visitors to experience the wonders of the Great Barrier Reef. Visits to the reef can be inhibited by the distance to be travelled offshore, occasional weather restrictions and the cost involved in making such a trip. To be opened in June 1987, the Great Barrier Reef Wonderland will make the reef come alive for many more people. The aquarium will consist of a large main tank containing live coral reef, a small tank containing predators, an extensive interpretive area and a theatrette for audiovisual displays. Dividing the main tank and the predator tank will be a transparent acrylic tunnel approximately three metres wide through which visitors will walk and be subjected to a genuine underwater viewing experience. Great Barrier Reef Wonderland will not only further enhance Townsville's international renown as a centre of excellence in tropical marine science but also provide an attraction of wonder and beauty to the tourists of the world. The list of new ventures funded by the Hawke Government goes on and on. The new $12m School of Technology on the Pimlico technical and further education campus is due for completion in October 1986. Totally funded by the Hawke Government, it is the largest single T AFE project currently underway in Australia. On the same campus, another Hawke Government building-the $4m School of Tourism and Hospitality-now has more than 600 students. The Federal Government bears the total cost of roadworks along the Bruce Highway. This financial year, the Hawke Government is spending tens of millions of dollars on road works in north Queensland, particularly along the Bruce Highway between Townsville and Ingham. Good roads are more than a strip of bitumen. They bring tourists, help industry and create jobs. Townsville is home to the Third Brigade of the Australian Army and is the site of a Royal Australian Air Force base. North Queenslanders applaud the resolve and commitment of the Hawke Government to a modern and strong Australian Defence Force. Total defence outlay in 1986-87 is estimated at $7.5 billion. This is increase of 11.1 per cent over 1985-86 outlays on defence and represents an underlying real growth of one per cent. The defence budget provides for the continued improvement of living and working conditions for defence personnel, for operating costs and for investment on weapons, equipment and facilities. The Budget also announced a $20.7m project to move the RAAF's No.9 helicopter squadron from Amberley to Townsville by early 1989. The move would follow the re-equipping of the squadron at Amberley with Sikorski Black Hawk helicopters. Detailed planning of the facilities required to support an increased helicopter presence at Townsville are already underway. Included will be a new parking apron, a hangar, workshops and administrative facilities expected to cost about $19m, as well as houses for married personnel which could cost up to $8m. The Budget provides $450,000 over the next three years to establish a north Queensland health surveillance unit. The unit will monitor and study the incidence and distribution of marine-based illnesses and other tropical illnesses which occur in northern Australia. I stress that the Federal Government alone is financing tropical health research in Townsville. The Queensland Government has refused to contribute towards the establishment of such a health unit. On 24 June 1986 a large number of persons attended a public meeting in Townsville in response to a massive publicity campaign by certain sections of the local media on what they perceived to be the state of the national economy. The committee organising the public meeting circulated a questionnaire to thousands of people in the Townsville region and I seek leave to table details of the committee's questions and the respondents' answers, as summarised by the committee. Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr LINDSAY
Title: AYES
text: The Federal Government is to provide up to $5m over the next three years towards Australia's hosting of the fifth International Festival of Pacific Arts, to be held in Townsville in August 1988. Festivals of Pacific arts are the main cultural events Australia shares with its Pacific neighbours. This financial year $300,000 has been allocated to commence planning for the festival and to establish an office in Townsville. A board of directors will be named soon and money should start to flow to the project in November. The festivals are a major means of cultural exchange. They draw together up to 2,000 people of diverse cultural backan grounds from over 25 nations through the South Pacific for traditional performances of song and dance, and exhibitions and demonstrations of traditional arts and crafts. As the festival will serve to highlight, under the Hawke Government Australia is emerging once again as a nation to be respected in the world. This Government has rejected conflict and confrontation and replaced it with co-operation and compassion. The Hawke Government has ended the drift, the division, the lack of direction, the loss of confidence, the absence of leadership and the blindness about where Australia was headed and what Australians could achieve together. We are creating a better, more caring, more tolerant, more diverse and more realistic Australia. It is a more cohesive, richer and enriched Australiaan Australia of which each citizen can be justly proud.

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Title: AYES
text: We are discussing the Appropriation Bill (No. I) 1986-87 and, on behalf of the Opposition, I move: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: 'whilst not opposing the passage of this Bill, the House condemns the Government for(I) the failure of the Budget to tackle Australia's fundamental economic problems, namely: (a) the record and rising level of overseas debt; (b) excessively high levels of government spending and taxation; (c) an inflation rate 4 times the average of our major trading partners; (d) interest rates once again approaching 20%; (e) a wages policy that does not take account of the capacity of individual enterprises to pay, and (f) the pernicious effects of the anti-business, anti-investment taxes such as the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax, and (2) the loss of Australia's AAA international credit rating following the failure of the Budget' It is now four weeks since the Treasurer (Mr Keating) introduced the much heralded Budget which was to solve all our economic problems. In the weeks leading up to the Budget the Australian dollar was under as'sault in foreign exchange markets. Almost a year of warning signals had produced from the Government nothing but deceit and prevarication, unwillingness to share with the Australian people the full extent of our difficulties and paralysis in the face of the emerging crisis. Month after month the figures were bad-inflation, balance of payments and rising foreign debt. Month after month the Opposition demanded that the Government face up to its responsibilities. We said that the Government should tighten fiscal policy, delay the March wage case and the productivity case, halt the legislation to impose new anti-business, anti-investment taxes, such as the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax, and remove foreign exchange controls. We first made a detailed statement to this effect on 3 January this year. The Government did not respond. The most powerful evidence of crisis began to build up in October and November of last year. Earlier-in August-the Government, in its Budget statements, warned of difficulties with the terms of trade. By marking down the dollar in November 1985 the foreign exchange markets delivered their second blunt warning to the Government that its policies were imperilling the Australian economy, having delivered a warning shot in February 1985. The warnings were ignored by the Government. High spending continued. The ludicrous charade of the March wage case and the productivity-superannuation deal continued with the Government presenting, in collusion with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, false evidence to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Commission was forced to acknowledge the weight of the evidence against the case on productivity concocted by the Government and the ACTU, yet demonstrated its subservience to the industrial might of the trade unions by giving them a licence to gain by industrial action what they could not gain by logical argument. Never was so clearly proclaimed the danger to economic good sense and industrial harmony presented by the current charter of the Commission. Having surrendered on wages policy, the Government refused to act on fiscal policy. It was self-evident in January that government spending had to be cut to reduce the deficit on our current account with the rest of the world. Yet nothing was done. The Opposition called for a mini-Budget in April or May to get spending cuts in place by the beginning of the new financial year-on I July-but nothing was done. Right up to 9 May this year the Treasurer misled the Australian public on the true state of the economy. On 9 May he treated his own formal advisory body-the Economic Planning Advisory Council-with contempt by telling it that the domestic economy was strong enough to withstand external pressures. Yet only five days later on the John Laws radio program he admitted that we were heading towards the economic status of a banana republic. The fact is that we are witnessing a massive failure of policy by the Hawke Government. For three and a half years it has been pursuing a policy direction which has been quite wrong for Australia. In March 1983 it had every opportunity to succeed. The economy was emerging from the recession caused by the wider world recession and a disastrous drought. The Fraser Government's wage pause was in place. The Government had the good will of practically the whole of the Australian community, including the business community. It had the ball at its feet. Tragically, it gambled with Australia's future security. It deliberately pumped up the economy by enormous increases in spending, financed by higher taxes and massive overseas borrowing. The wages pause of the coalition Government was abandoned in favour of the inflationary policy of wage indexation demanded by the trade union movement. Taxes and business charges were lifted to their highest levels ever. Even if our external trading position had remained strong, the disastrous impact of these policies on Australia's competitiveness and economic strength would have worked its way through. The failure to respond to our deteriorating external position, evident now for a good twelve months, has merely intensified the inevitable crash which has occurred. The simple truth is that the Government's economic policies have failed. The accord has been a disaster for Australia. The irresponsible Budgets of the last years have led inexorably to the worse crisis since the Great Depression. The Treasurer has used Australia's previously high credit rating to gamble with Australia's future on the world commodity markets. He recklessly drove the Australian economy on borrowed money in the hope that commodity prices would turn up. He trod the high wire, to the applause of the impressionable crowd and those who hoped to gain from his gambling. However, the croupier's spin did not turn in his favour. Commodity prices did not turn up. We were left with massive foreign debt and a crippling burden of interest and capital repayment. The Treasurer has betrayed his fiduciary responsibility to the Australian people. He has left us defenceless, with no policy for recovery. The Government has no strategy; it has no sense of purpose. It lunges in all directions except those necessary to correct the damage its policies have done to Australia. This Budget signals the Government's failure. It has not cut spending, it has not cut taxes. It has not put value back into the dollar, it has not generated investment, and by its reckless gambling it has destroyed Australia's proudest symbol of financial stability and trust, its AAA international credit rating. This Treasurer, proclaimed the world's greatest by an international money magazine at the height of his gambling spree with our money, has now been cashiered by the bank. What a shameful episode. What a record to leave in Australia's financial history, to have been the Treasurer to lose our top rating for credit worthiness! Perhaps it is no surprise when we remind ourselves that the Treasurer greatly admired J. T. Lang, who recommended default in the 1930s, and was ignominiously dismissed by the Governor of New South Wales before he could bring this country into disrepute. What of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)? He has let Australians down very badly. He has neither the strength nor the vision to do what has to be done. He believes in nothing and leads no one. He is a failed Prime Minister at the head of a failed government. The nature of Australia's fundamental problem is plain for all to see. It is understood by ordinary people a great deal better than it is understood by the Hawke Government. It is simply that governments in Australia at State and Federal levels have been living beyond their means. Governments are spending far more than the Australian people are prepared to pay for through their taxes and the borrowings needed to sustain this level of spending are higher than three Australia can afford. Government spending has moved far beyond the point where it can be sustained by the revenue base available to the Government. Indeed, the Government has spread its largesse so widely that even vital health services are starved while frivolous activities flourish. In every respect the Hawke Government has worsened this problem of overspending. Spending for Federal purposes has risen each year to higher and higher levels and tax collections have risen to the highest levels in Australia's history. Interest payments on the Government's debt are now the second highest item of Federal spending after social welfare. These interest payments can be funded in the end only by higher taxes. The Hawke Government's policies have been an economic version of Chernobyl: One by one all the safety valves in the Australian economy have been shut down until the critical chain reaction has occurred, blasting the floor out from under the economy and the dollar. Every Australian is suffering from the fallout, through high taxes, high interest rates and rising prices. The remedy is not complicated. It is not difficult to see or to understand. It is available to any government with the courage not to sacrifice the Australian people in order to appease special interest groups or trade union bureaucrats. The remedy is to reduce government spending to levels which Australia can afford and which the Australian people can comfortably and willingly pay for, without an oppressive burden of taxes or interest rates. I do not want to suggest that the solution lies wholly in the hands of government. Ultimately, it lies very much in the hands of the Australian people. It depends in the end on a recognition of the limits of what government can do for them and that the quality of their lives is really in their own hands. Nor do I want to suggest that the whole failure of the Government lies in its excessive spending. The competitive efficiency of Australia in a fiercely competitive world depends greatly on the capacity of its industries to adapt freely to changing circumstances, both in their work practices and in their cost flexibility. Yet the Hawke Government, as a conscious act of policy, has reinforced the power and influence of the most reactionary force in Australia today, the trade union bureaucracy. The very same people who forced restrictive work practices on whole industries through bUllying and intimidation, who shut down the petrol supplies of Sydney and Melbourne to secure additional benefits for employees already earning $40,000 per year, who closed the ports for a week after the Prime Minister's national broadcast calling for effort and sacrifice, are feted and garlanded by the Prime Minister and his Ministers, invited to the innermost councils of government, favoured in the decision-making process and granted a power of veto over the government's most important decisions. The Government has not merely failed to curb the excessive power of bureaucratic trade unionism; it has used all its energies to strengthen it. Not only has it failed to begin the process of reform of our outdated and inefficient industrial relations system, but it is preparing to entrench it further by legislating to implement the recommendations of the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, which ran up a white flag in the face of trade union aggression. The troika of excessive spending, high taxation and overpowerful trade unionism has been driven over the Australian economy, leaving it crippled, bereft of an adequate fiscal and wages policy. Last November this weakness was exposed. Without curbs on spending and wage levels the government had to rely on high interest rates to prop up the dollar. As a result, interest rates rose to their highest real levels since the Great Depression of the 1930s. This Budget was supposed to provide the remedy. Not surprisingly, it has failed. Yes, the deficit was reduced by $2.2 billion, but $1.5 billion of this came from higher taxes and $0.6 billion came from windfall gains arising from Reserve Bank currency dealing. So we have no credible fiscal policy. What about wages? We are told that at a time when our inflation rate is more than four times that of our major trading partners and more than 16 times that of our main trading partner, Japan, the Government will humbly beg the trade union movement to accept a miserable 2 per cent discounting of wages against inflation. We are told that to ask for more would be 'industrially unrealistic'. On top of this the most bullying and thuggish unions are encouraged by this Government to extract 3 per cent superannuation contributions from terrorised employers on behalf of conscripted employees, 86 per cent of whom do not believe in compulsory unionism. What sort of a cloud cuckoo land of industrial relations do we live in, especially when those who quite legitimately question the system are referred to by an hysterical Prime Minister as 'political troglodytes' and 'economic lunatics' and accused of treason by the Minister for Trade? For this misguided and divided Government, the game is up. The international financial community believed its prospectus, backed it with its money, lost that money when the dollar fell, and has now lost confidence in the Government. Business, both foreign and domestic, has ceased to invest in Australia. Australians themselves are investing off-shore in increasing volume. The Australian people are fearful of their future and distrustful of the Government. The Prime Minister behaves erratically and unpredictably. The Labor Government's own grass roots organisation is beginning to disown it. And, of course, Australia's families are left poorer by this Government, with higher Government charges, higher prices, higher taxes and the increasing threat of unemployment. We in the Opposition recognise the seriousness of the task we face. As soon as this discredited Government can be removed by due democratic process, we shall begin our task. We are not of a mind this time to come into office merely with the intention of tidying up. We will indeed have to tidy up, but we will also make fundamental changes in the economic and social structures of Australia that will set the course well into the next century. The industrial relations system set up by the Liberal Alfred Deakin in 1904 to redress the imbalance of power between capital and labour will be changed for the same Liberal reasons, although this time in the other direction. The overreliance on government will be reduced and Australia will be transformed into a country of greater self-reliance and self-confidence as we move into our third century of settlement. The taxation system will be changed to remove the Keating barriers to entrepreneurship and investment, and also to provide incentive to personal and corporate taxpayers. Foreign investment controls will be removed. The transport and communications systems will be opened up to cost-cutting competition. Government interference and regulation will be reduced to the minimum. In the classical Liberal tradition, all aspects of our society will be examined. Those that work well will be retained and strengthened, those that can be improved will be improved and those that serve no useful purpose will be abandoned. We are determined that this fortunate, peaceful, well-educated yet self-indulthey gent society of Australia will break free of its self-imposed shackles and earn its place as one of the leading nations of the fastest growing region of the world. Ours is not a cold and calculating economic purpose, unrelated to the needs and aspirations of ordinary people. Change will not be made for the sake of change, or in pursuit of some untried ideology. But change is needed, and widespread change, that will bring practical and tangible development and benefits to individuals and their families, and allow them to shape their own lives with security and hope for the future. We look forward to the opportunity to bring about this change-not by direction of government, but by releasing the energies of the Australian people. We are convinced that it will not be long before we are called back into service.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: AYES
text: Is the amendment seconded?  reserve my right to speak.  appointing to listen to the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). As has been said, he could drum up only 22 of his own members and coalition partners to listen to him.   am I a shadow Minister. The performance of the honourable gentleman was disappointing. Mr John Brown-You have great quality.  great quality on this side of the chamber at all times, as the Minister points out. I want to address some of the issues raised by the shadow Minister. He has talked about the necessity to try to cut government expenditures; and what do we find in the Budget? The Budget deficit has been reduced from $5.726 billion to $3.503 billion. The deficit has been cut in the Budget by some $2.223 billion, to $3.503 billion. If we had taken no action on outlays and receipts, the deficit would have been $7.5 billion. This is a government which has had to face the hard task of trying to address and get right the nation's economy. The feature of Opposition speakers that I do not understand is the confrontationist language that they use and the constant harassment of the ordinary men and women of Australia, whom want to blame for the current economic situation, in particular the current account deficit. They suggest that somehow the ordinary men and women are responsible for getting us into the present position and that they should be willing to see wages slashed, slashed and slashed again and not merely accept the wage restraint that we have provided under the accord. It is not necessary to be an economic genius to realise that if wages are slashed and slashed again we shall not land one extra tonne of wheat, wool, iron ore or aluminium in our export markets. The slashing of wages will not help. The Government's real accomplishments have been achieved by working in co-operation with the trade union movement. The Opposition keeps on talking about the evil influence of the trade union movement when it has produced real labour unit cost reductions so that these costs in 1986 are comparable to the levels that applied in the 1960s and 1970s. I could understand the constant chant about trade union power and the constant attack on the trade union movement if we had record levels of industrial disputation, but we do not. We have the lowest level of industrial disputation, from so-called evil trade union power, that we have had for the past 18 years. It is the best that we have had. I want to rehearse some of the real gains that the Government and the trade union movement, through the prices and incomes accord, have achieved. (Quorum formed) most I was outlining some of the real achievements accomplished by this Government and the trade union movement in the form of the prices and incomes accord. We ought to recall the legacy left to us after the Fraser years by that Treasurer, dishonest John Howard. He provided record unemployment and double digit inflation, and real hope for the future was taken away from so many of our families. The fastest growing industry in Australia was the dole queues of the Commonwealth Employment Service offices. That was the economic record and legacy of the previous Government. What have we accomplished? We have accomplished the fastest economic growth of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. We have had the most consistent period of sustained high level growth since the early 1970s, we have had the fastest employment growth rate in the world, and we are the only OECD country projected to have a further fall in unemployment. More than two-thirds of the job growth has been in full time jobs. Almost 90 per cent of jobs created have been in the private se.tor. Fifty-seven percent of new jobs have gone to women, and a total of 630,000 jobs have been created since April 1983. Inflation prior to devaluation has been more than halved. Profitability, as a proportion of gross domestic product, rose from 11 per cent to 15.5 per cent. Industrial disputation is at its lowest level for over 18 years. As I mentioned, real unit labour costs have been significantly reduced and are now below the levels obtaining in the late 1960s and 1970s. Opposition speakers have drawn attention to Australia's inflation rate, as though this is the only measure of competitiveness in the economy. I point out to honourable members opposite that if the 6 per cent differential between our inflation rate and that of our international competitors were maintained, it would take until 1996 to erode the competitive gains that have been achieved in this economy. Of course, we would all like to see inflation reduced and that is why we are proposing a 2 per cent discount in the next wage round. We will get it down, but let us not be side tracked into trying to suggest that the inflation rate is the only measure of competitiveness and that somehow this is preventing Australia from competing. The major problem we have is in our current account deficit, which is currently running at $14 billion per annum. But that is not a situation that has been brought about by the trade union movement or by some aspect of government policy. Most rational economic observers are happy to say that the real problem has been a real decline in our terms of trade; that is, the money or the price we get when we export goods. Had we not had that decline in the last 12 months, our current account deficit, rather than being projected at $14 billion per annum, would have been $8 billion. I will give three examples of what has happened to the price of our commodities. Between 1980-81 and 1985-86 wheat prices fell from $US 181.90 to $US 133 a tonne-a fall of 27 per cent. The most recent price has not been $US 133 but $US103 a tonne. The same applied to coal. Between 1981-82 and 1985-86 average coal export prices fell from $US54.85 a tonne to $US39.41 a tonne-down 28 per cent. Between 1981-82 and 1985-86 Japanese contract ore prices fell from $US21.90 a tonne to $US 16.1 O-down 26 per cent. Of course, this Government is addressing Australia's loss of prices in its export markets. This is what this Budget is all about. I want to get back to my opening point. It is not the ordinary men and women of Australia who are to blame for this situation. A wage cut of 20 or 30 per cent that is obviously advocated by the New Right will not solve our problem. In fact, I refer to a Committee for Economic Development of Australia study on exploiting opportunities in the Pacific basin. That study concluded that, despite business perception, cost factors are not the real problem. The real problems are associated with developing skills in marketing and technology, and with competing in terms of value added to the consumer rather than associated with prices alone. There is no doubt that we have a long way to go in solving the problem. The difference between this Government and the Opposition is that we are saying: 'We have to face up to it as a nation'. We are not trying to blame one sector over another. We all have a contribution to make, but may I say none more so than the business entrepreneurs in Australia. We will overcome our problems-not tomorrow, not in the next three months, but over time.
