Speaker: Mr SCOTT
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: 1 would like to thank the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), who has just sat down, for advising me that he was going to raise this garbage in the House tonight. I raised this matter in the House on 25 March 1985. It is recorded at page 858 of Hansard. I am quite happy to repeat what I said because I think it is very telling on the difference between the two groups here-the Government and the Opposition. I said at that time: I am pleased to advise this House of the fine work being carried out in Australia by such organisations as the Campaign Against Racial Exploitation. The driving force is Jim and Irene Gale, two wonderfully dedicated people. I interpose that, unfortunately, Australia is the sadder because of the passing of Jim Gale. But I am glad to say that the Government, in its sponsorship of peace awards, saw fit to find that Jim Gale in his dedication to the peoples of Africa in particular was a person worthy of being awarded posthumously a peace award. His work continues. I am extremely proud to have been associated with him and his wife at that time. I will continue to work with my colleague the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) in trying to do something for the oppressed people of South Africa. I went on to say at that time: There is also the work of Eddie Funde, the representative of the African National Congress. I try to assist as a trustee of the African Liberation Trust I point out that that is shown in my personal details that were tabled in the House not so long ago; so there is nothing sinister or mysterious about my involvement. I went on: I commend the Minister for Foreign Affairs on his statement. I congratulate the Opposition shadow Minister for his support. I would be delighted to see more of my colleagues support the Campaign Against Racial Exploitation and the African Liberation Trust Fund. The reason I mentioned the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and the shadow Minister at the time was that earlier in the speech I had said: In the period available to me I would like to address some specific matters of great concern to Australia's standing as a nation in today's world. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) has recently in this House condemned the outrageous killing of black people in South Africa on 21 March this year. Similar killings at Sharpeville were carried out by the South African Government 25 years to the day before these recent killings. The Minister, speaking on behalf of this Labor Government, reaffirmed the Government's total opposition to the injustice and inhumanity of apartheid. The shadow Minister, the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), wholeheartedly endorsed this Government's statement. I applaud the shadow Minister for his stand. I hope he can hold that line. I want briefly to say that the letter referred to did have wide circulation. I think there must have been a bit of a mix-up in the mail because one of the recipients was a fellow by the name of Bruce Ruxton of the Returned Services League of Australia. Something must have happened with the mail because the letter to Mr Ruxton somehow got lost and it was only in the last six weeks that he received the letter. I presume he received it only then. He had the kindness to reply to me and express his views about organisations such as the South West Africa People's Organisation and the African National Congress. I responded and said that I was pleased to receive his reply. I reminded him of his recent tour of the Soviet Union and his very complimentary remarks about the Soviet system. Those remarks appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald. I would be more than delighted at the right time to table that letter to Bruce Ruxton and his subsequent reply, because I think it is with that kind of dialogue, without the hysteria that one gets from Queensland Premiers who are senile, that one gets a proper appreciation of the issues.

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: 1 do intend to speak on a matter relating to my electorate. Fund. However, I have just been advised of a letter dated 12 September 1986 from the South West Africa People's Organisation to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) seeking assistance from the Government. The letter, referring to support required, states in part: The first concerns our need for help in training Namibians in preparation for their role in a future independent Namibia. This dispels any suggestion that SW APO is not a terrorist organisation. The honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott), who spoke a moment ago, stands condemned as a person who supports terrorism, along with other members of the Australian Labor Party. I fully support what the Queensland Premier has said and the people of Australia will no doubt condemn the ALP for its weak-kneed approach to terrorism in this country. We have the Palestine Liberation Organisation, SW APO and other organisations which are operating under the auspices of this Government. I now wish to refer to a problem experienced by a bus company in my electorate, Kangaroo Bus Lines, which in February 1985 received a letter of demand, a log of claims and working conditions, from the Transport Workers Union of Australia, the leadership of which in many cases comprises industrial thugs. The conditions that were asked of the company were ridiculous to say the least. Among other things the unions demanded a minimum of $1,500 a week for all employees, a minimum of $100 a week in addition to all other payments as extra payment, and a rest pause of 30 minutes for each hour worked. The reply from Kangaroo Bus Lines stated: Having read the enclosed claim, I find it hard to believe that any organisation could expect a privately owned bus operation to remain in business if it had to meet the conditions as stated in your letter of demand. If these conditions were forced upon us, we would have no alternative but to close down our operations and stand down all employees. The letter concluded in effectly informing the TWU that the bus company was not interested in being covered under a Federal award, and the company mistakenly assumed that this was the end of the matter. In May of this year a staff member of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations approached the company to inspect its business operations. Since it was established the business has operated on the understanding that it was covered by a State award; but, unfortunately, according to the inspector the business somehow had become subject to a Federal award. How could this happen in a democratic society? Quite simply, the union concerned managed to include the business in a Federal award through a tactic known as setting up a roping in dispute. The Department of Employment and Industrial Relations explained in its letter to me of 25 June: Federal awards apply only to actual parties to the dispute in settlement of which the award concerned was made. Federal industrial tribunals ordinarily have no power to add new respondents to an award by variation. Where it is desired to extend the scope of an existing award to new respondents, it is necessary first to create a new dispute or disputes with such employers on the subject matters involved in the existing award. Such a dispute is known as a roping in dispute and the award made in settlement is known as a roping in award. This ridiculous log of claims that no company could hope to implement effectively placed Kangaroo Bus Lines in dispute with the TWU. Kangaroo Bus Lines did not hear again from any industrial tribunal. It did not hear again from the union and it thought that was the end of the matter. But an inspector came from the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. I was advised that Kangaroo Bus Lines had been roped into a Federal award and that come hell or high water there was nothing that Kangaroo Bus Lines could do about it except to apply for a variation of the award to exclude it from the award. I am certain that the people of Australia would agree with me that it is criminal that a union could drag in a business in this way without previously advising it that the matter was coming before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, resulting in the company being bound by a Federal award. That is a ridiculous example of excessive union power. Not only did the employees of Kangaroo Bus Lines not wish to be included in the Federal award, but it also was in their best interest not to be so included. They now face the prospect of losing their jobs because of the onerous conditions of the Federal award which Kangaroo Bus Lines is not able to afford.

Speaker: Dr BLEWETT
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: 1 would like to make a few remarks in response to the remarks made earlier this evening by the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). I say first of all that I am particularly disappointed that the honourable member, for whom I have had considerable respect, should join the Premier of Queensland in idiocies and simplifications concerning the very difficult issue in South Africa. I have for a long time been sympathetic to the black majority in South Africa and their struggle for rights which all of us in this society claim and have. I have followed their struggle. Indeed, I suggest that the honourable member for Farrer should examine much more deeply the problem in southern Africa before he makes the kinds of comments to which he lent himself tonight. Having long had this attitude, I must say that, when I was in South Africa in 1980 and visited Soweto and saw the contrast between the living conditions in Soweto and those in much of white Johannesburg, I found it understandable that that society has enormous internal tensions and problems. It is no good simply talking about terrorism without understanding the deep problems of that society. But honourable members do not have to believe me on this issue. I refer to the following quotation: There is no peaceful legal means in which black people in South Africa can seek to exercise political pressure on the Government because all the legal means of exercising political pressure that we know in a country like Australia, have been successively denied to black South Africans. So, they can't do anything legally to try and make their point known. If I was living without any political rights of any kind, and if over forty years I and my parents had not been able to achieve any political rights, and if I was living in the state in which people were in South Africa, then I would say if people would not respond to normal political pressure then ultimately you can't blame them if they pick up arms. Those remarks, of course, were made by the exLiberal Prime Minister of this country. Again, he is someone who has been prepared to study and understand the problems in southern Africa. So when a group of Australians whom I very much respect, including my colleague the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott), Cliff Dolan, Professor Manning Clark, Don Dunstan, and the Bishop of Newcastle asked me to join in a trust fund to raise money simply in order to fund the personnel in an information office in this country for the African National Congress and the South West Africa People's Organisation, I was happy and honoured to take part. I point out that the whole purpose of this fund has simply been to fund and provide support for the personnel of that office so that their point of view-the point of view of the black majority in South Africa-can be presented in that country. They do not have the resources that the Government of South Africa has. H is important to consider this when one listens to the honourable member for Farreran honourable member for whom, as I say, I have considerable respect-make his simplistic statements. One expects nothing better from the Premier of Queensland, but one does expect better from the honourable member for Farrer. One would hope that he would make the effort to listen to the arguments that the people are presenting through the information office of the ANC and SW APO. I welcome this debate, because one of the chief benefits of Sir Joh BjelkePetersen's utterances has been to arouse interest in this trust fund. I hope that this debate will do the same.
